name: Thompson’s or Simmond’s Test
purpose: To assess for Achilles tendon rupture.
instructions: Patient lies prone with feet hanging off the edge of the table.
Examiner squeezes the calf muscle.
Positive: Absence of plantar flexion indicates Achilles tendon rupture.

name: Talar Tilt Test
purpose: To assess the integrity of the calcaneofibular ligament (CFL).
instructions: Patient seated with legs hanging.
Examiner stabilizes the distal tibia and inverts the calcaneus.
Positive: Excessive laxity or pain relative to the unaffected side.

name: Anterior Drawer Test (Ankle)
purpose: To assess the integrity of the anterior talofibular ligament (ATFL).
instructions: Patient supine with foot in 20° plantar flexion.
Examiner stabilizes the tibia and pulls the calcaneus anteriorly.
Positive: Excessive anterior translation of the talus.

name: Squeeze Test
purpose: To assess for syndesmosis (high ankle) injury.
instructions: Patient seated or supine.
Examiner squeezes the tibia and fibula together at mid-calf level.
Positive: Pain elicited at the distal tibiofibular syndesmosis.

name: Tinel’s Sign
purpose: To detect irritated nerves by percussing over the nerve.
instructions: Examiner taps over the suspected nerve pathway (e.g., carpal tunnel or tarsal tunnel).
Positive: Tingling or 'pins and needles' sensation in the nerve distribution.

name: Dorsiflexion–Eversion Test
purpose: To assess for Tarsal Tunnel Syndrome.
instructions: Examiner passively dorsiflexes and everts the foot to its end-range.
Hold for 5-10 seconds while percussing over the tarsal tunnel.
Positive: Reproduction of symptoms along the plantar aspect of the foot.

name: Spurling’s Test
purpose: To assess for cervical radiculopathy.
instructions: Patient's head is side-flexed to the affected side.
Examiner applies a downward axial load to the head.
Positive: Pain radiating into the arm on the same side.

name: Cervical Distraction Test
purpose: To assess for cervical radiculopathy (relief test).
instructions: Patient supine.
Examiner applies upward traction to the patient's head.
Positive: Reduction or elimination of radicular symptoms.

name: Maudsley’s Test
purpose: To assess for lateral epicondylalgia (Tennis Elbow) involving the extensor digitorum.
instructions: Patient's elbow is extended.
Examiner resists extension of the third digit (middle finger).
Positive: Pain over the lateral epicondyle.

name: Cozen’s Test
purpose: To assess for lateral epicondylalgia.
instructions: Patient's elbow is flexed to 90°, forearm pronated.
Examiner resists active wrist extension and radial deviation.
Positive: Sudden pain at the lateral epicondyle.

name: Mill’s Sign
purpose: To assess for lateral epicondylalgia.
instructions: Examiner passively pronates the forearm, flexes the wrist fully, and extends the elbow.
Positive: Pain over the lateral epicondyle.

name: Valgus Stress Test
purpose: To assess the integrity of the Medial Collateral Ligament (MCL).
instructions: Patient supine, knee in 20-30° flexion.
Examiner applies a valgus (inward) force to the knee while stabilizing the ankle.
Positive: Excessive medial opening or pain.

name: O’Driscoll’s Hook Test
purpose: To assess for distal biceps tendon rupture.
instructions: Patient's elbow is flexed to 90°, forearm supinated.
Examiner attempts to hook the lateral edge of the biceps tendon with their finger.
Positive: Inability to hook the tendon.

name: Straight-Leg Raise (Lasegue’s Test)
purpose: To assess for lumbar nerve root irritation.
instructions: Patient supine.
Examiner slowly lifts the symptomatic leg with the knee extended.
Positive: Radicular pain below the knee between 30-70°.

name: Bragard Test
purpose: Confirmatory test for neural origin in SLR.
instructions: Perform SLR to the level of pain, then lower the leg 5°.
Passively dorsiflex the foot.
Positive: Reproduction of radicular symptoms.

name: Bowstring Test
purpose: To assess for sciatic nerve tension.
instructions: Perform SLR to paint point, then flex the knee slightly (20°).
Apply pressure to the popliteal nerve in the fossa.
Positive: Reproduction of radicular symptoms.

name: Bicycle Stress Test
purpose: To differentiate between neurogenic and vascular claudication.
instructions: Patient pedals a stationary bike in an upright posture until symptoms appear.
Patient pedals again while leaning forward (flexed spine).
Positive for neurogenic: Increased exercise tolerance when flexed.

name: Two-Stage Treadmill Test
purpose: To assess for spinal stenosis.
instructions: Test 1: Patient walks on a level treadmill.
Test 2: Patient walks on an uphill treadmill.
Positive: Symptoms take longer to appear or are less severe on the uphill (flexed) walk.

name: Lumbar Extension-Loading Test
purpose: To assess for facet joint syndrome or spondylolysis.
instructions: Patient stands and extends the lumbar spine while rotating toward the symptomatic side.
Positive: Reproduction of localized low back pain.

name: Femoral Nerve Stretch Test (Wasserman Sign)
purpose: To assess for L2-L4 nerve root irritation.
instructions: Patient prone.
Examiner flexes the patient's knee and then extends the hip.
Positive: Pain in the anterior thigh.

name: Kernig Test
purpose: To assess for meningeal irritation or dural tension.
instructions: Patient supine with hip and knee flexed to 90°.
Examiner attempts to passively extend the knee.
Positive: Resistance to extension and pain in the neck or back.

name: Milgram Test
purpose: To assess for increased intrathecal pressure (e.g., disc herniation).
instructions: Patient supine.
Patient is asked to lift both legs 2 inches off the table and hold for 30 seconds.
Positive: Inability to hold or reproduction of symptoms.

name: Lateral Lumbar Flexion (Finger Tip to Floor Test)
purpose: To assess lumbar mobility and asymmetry.
instructions: Patient stands with feet together.
Patient slides their hand down the side of their leg as far as possible.
Measure distance from third finger to floor.
Positive: Significant asymmetry between sides.

name: Modified Schober’s Test
purpose: To measure lumbar spine flexion range of motion.
instructions: Mark S2 spinous process and 10cm above, 5cm below.
Patient bends forward as far as possible.
Positive: Extension of distance less than 5cm suggests restricted mobility (e.g., AS).

name: Painful Arc Test
purpose: To assess for subacromial impingement.
instructions: Patient actively abducts the arm in the scapular plane.
Positive: Pain between 60° and 120° of abduction.

name: Neer Impingement Sign
purpose: To assess for subacromial impingement.
instructions: Examiner stabilizes the scapula and passively flexes the arm to its end-range.
Positive: Pain in the subacromial region.

name: Hawkins–Kennedy Test
purpose: To assess for subacromial impingement.
instructions: Patient's shoulder and elbow flexed to 90°.
Examiner forces internal rotation of the humerus.
Positive: Pain in the subacromial region.

name: Jobe’s Test
purpose: To assess the supraspinatus tendon.
instructions: Arm at 90° abduction, 30° horizontal flexion, full internal rotation ('thumb down').
Examiner applies downward pressure while patient resists.
Positive: Pain or weakness.

name: Empty Can Test (Supraspinatus)
purpose: Identical to Jobe's test, specifically for supraspinatus.
instructions: Abduct arm to 90°, 30° forward, internal rotation.
Resist downward force.
Positive: Weakness or pain.

name: Infraspinatus Test
purpose: To assess the infraspinatus tendon.
instructions: Arm at side, elbow flexed to 90°.
Examiner resists the patient’s attempt at external rotation.
Positive: Pain or weakness.

name: Subscapularis (Belly Press Test)
purpose: To assess the subscapularis muscle when internal rotation is limited.
instructions: Patient places hand on belly and presses inward.
Positive: Elbow drops behind the plane of the body or inability to press.

name: Lag Sign (External Rotation)
purpose: To assess for full-thickness infraspinatus/supraspinatus tears.
instructions: Arm at side, flexed elbow, examiner passively rotates arm to full external rotation.
Patient is asked to hold the position.
Positive: 'Lag' or inability to maintain the position.

name: Drop Sign
purpose: To assess for infraspinatus tears.
instructions: Arm in 90° abduction, elbow flexed 90°, full external rotation.
Examiner releases the arm and patient tries to hold.
Positive: Arm 'drops' toward internal rotation.

name: Lift-Off Test
purpose: To assess the subscapularis muscle.
instructions: Patient places the back of their hand on their lumbar spine.
Patient is asked to lift the hand away from the back.
Positive: Inability to lift the hand.

name: Speed Test
purpose: To assess for bicipital tendinopathy.
instructions: Patient's arm extended, forearm supinated.
Examiner resists active shoulder flexion from 0 to 60°.
Positive: Pain in the bicipital groove.

name: Yergason’s Test
purpose: To assess for bicipital tendinopathy or SLAP lesions.
instructions: Elbow flexed to 90°, forearm pronated.
Examiner resists the patient’s attempt to supinate and externally rotate.
Positive: Pain in the bicipital groove.

name: O’Brien’s Test
purpose: To assess for SLAP lesions or AC joint pathology.
instructions: Part 1: Arm 90° flexion, 10° adduction, full internal rotation. Resist downward force.
Part 2: Repeat with full external rotation.
Positive: Pain during Part 1 that is relieved during Part 2.

name: Apprehension Test
purpose: To assess for anterior shoulder instability.
instructions: Arm 90° abduction, 90° external rotation.
Examiner slowly increases external rotation.
Positive: Patient looks apprehensive or expresses fear of dislocation.

name: Fulcrum’s Test
purpose: To assess for anterior shoulder instability.
instructions: Perform Apprehension Test while placing a hand under the glenohumeral joint (fulcrum).
Positive: Reproduction of symptoms or apprehension.

name: Drawer’s Test (Knee)
purpose: To assess the integrity of the ACL or PCL.
instructions: Patient supine, knee flexed to 90°.
Examiner pulls the tibia anteriorly (ACL) or pushes posteriorly (PCL).
Positive: Excessive translation of the tibia.
